comments:
Clinical Research in Emergency Medicine I is an LPS course that is designed to
teach students the fundamentals of clinical research. It highlights basic research design,
research ethics, data collection, and good clinical practices. Students work closely with
faculty in the Emergency Department at CHOP and HUP, engaging in screening,
recruiting, and consenting patients for a variety of studies. The course also includes a
supplemental seminar series that introduces students to innovative, focused areas of
medical research. This course stresses independent thinking, professional responsibility,
and personal accountability.
Nearly all students reported learning a lot from their experience working in the
Emergency Department and found the clinical aspect of the course to be both “enjoyable”
and “valuable.” One student described it as an “interesting introduction to clinical
research,” and another reported that it was “realistic” to what students will encounter in
their futures in medicine.
Overall, students reported feeling frustrated with Dr. Hollander for being
“ambiguous about grading,” especially for the clinical portion, and “unwilling to discuss
the class, exams, and grades.” Dr. Hollander posted answers to exams but would not
address students’ individual concerns. One student noted that Dr. Hollander’s failure to
discuss topics related to exams “stymies full understanding and can leave students
confused.”
Grades for this course were determined by: two midterm exams, a final exam, and
a clinical portion. Students generally agreed that the midterms were “difficult.” While a
couple of students thought the exams tested “relevant knowledge” and were
“straightforward,” others expressed frustration with their “tricky wording.” The second
midterm tested students on “operational material” and knowledge of hospital procedures,
which a couple of students found difficult to prepare for and noted that students’ grades
were lower for this exam compared to the others. The final seemed more “fair,”
however. Overall, students found the course to be valuable, though demanding, and one
student recommended that it be taken by “every student who is pre-health bound.” The
permission of the instructor is required for enrollment in this course.
